title: Rugby holy land awaits World Cup pilgrimage
text:
Rugby holy land awaits World Cup pilgrimage AMELIA ROMANOS Last updated 05:00, August 12 2015 Amelia Romanos 
The Rugby School field where William Webb Ellis 'invented' the sport. 
A small Warwickshire town is expecting to be inundated with rugby fans when the World Cup kicks off in the UK next month. 
The relatively unknown English town is not unlike many others across the country. It has lots of churches, a bunch of pubs, bright red Royal Mail post boxes, and a Marks and Spencer's. 
There's not a whole heap to do and the shopping opportunities are dismal. 
But it has a point of difference that will spark the World Cup pilgrimage: The town is called Rugby. 
It was there, in 1823, that a young William Webb Ellis ignored the traditions of football, took the ball in his hands, and ran down a Rugby School field. 
A plaque commemorating William Webb Ellis at Rugby School. Photo: Amelia Romanos 
Some say he was cheating, but whatever the ethics behind it, unto us, rugby was born - the school is now the Bethlehem of the sport. 
Local businesses have definitely cashed in on the historic connection, with Webb Ellis' name plastered on pubs and hotels. 
A statue of the great man himself stands near the town centre, across the road from the Webb Ellis Rugby Museum, which displays rugby memorabilia dating back to the 1800s. Ad Feedback 
But for true fans, the crucial stop is about a block further up the road, at Rugby School itself. 
The exclusive private school, well known within England, runs year-round tours and has launched a new one specifically for the World Cup. 
Rugby School archivist Rusty MacLean, clearly the go-to expert for everything Rugby, says the tours have become increasingly popular, so much so that he no longer runs them and a crew of local guides have been trained. 
The tour takes in the field where Webb Ellis made history, and a school museum with rugby relics, including a crimson cap that is believed to be part of the original uniforms and the item behind the term 'international cap'. 
There are a host of bizarre rugby facts on offer, including that a try was not originally the points-scoring achievement it is now. Rather, when the player got the ball down over the line he simply got a 'try' at kicking a goal. 
Pictures from more than a century ago depict games that could apparently go on for days and in which hundreds of people would participate. 
A statue of William Webb Ellis near Rugby's town centre. Photo: Amelia Romanos 
But the school's not all rugby. 
The school's alumni is a who's who of world famous names outside the sports world, including writers Lewis Carroll and Salman Rushdie, former prime minister Neville Chamberlain, and actor Robert Hardy, known for his role as Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter film series. 
The school's former headmaster, Thomas Arnold, sometimes credited as being the creator of 'the English gentleman', may be among the most famous Rugbeians. 
Among the other stops on the tour is a protected building that is the oldest surviving cricket pavilion in the country, dating back to 1851. 
Another highlight is Arnold's former two-storey classroom, which might as well be a Harry Potter film set, and includes panels from old desks showing off centuries of graffiti. 
MacLean says it's rare for a visitor to know the history behind the school, and the tour is a good opportunity to show it off and also address the biggest misconception about his home: 
"I can't tell you how many people say, 'Wow, a whole town named after the sport!'"
